question: What is a strawman / strawman theory ? I saw a video on youtube talking about US citizens being property and the word strawman kept popping up . Edit : I 'm not talking about the strawman argument that 's related to something else Please explain like I'm five.
responses: A stawman argument is when you misrepresents your opponents views and argue against that misrepresentation rather than your opponents real points . Example from wikipedia : > A : We should relax the laws on beer . > B : No , any society with unrestricted access to intoxicants loses its work ethic and goes only for immediate gratification . > The proposal was to relax laws on beer . Person B has exaggerated this to a position harder to defend , i.e. , " unrestricted access to intoxicants " . It is a logical fallacy because Person A never made that claim .

question: How do they find out the information that goes on Nutrition Facts labels ? Like number of calories , fat content , vitamin content , etc . etc . Please explain like I'm five.

Instead of actually analyzing every new product , the company just adds together the nutrition info of the base ingredients . As for how the base vitamin components are discovered , that involves a lot of Chemistry that is well beyond my grasp , but suffice it to say it takes a chemistry lab .

question: Why is it mostly men who are colorblind ? I 'm Curious . I am a male who can see minute color differences but have many friends who ca n't tell red from blue . Please explain like I'm five.
responses: Color blindness is a sex linked trait . Men get an " XY " sex chromosome and women get an " XX " sex chromosome . However , the " Y " is n't really a whole chromosome it 's just a tiny piece so all all the traits are lumped into that one " X " and if anyone of those traits are " bad " ( such as color blindness ) the body is forced to take it because it does n't have another " X " to pull a " good " trait from . For a woman to be colorblind she has to have both traits be " bad " so it 's less common .

question: Why does correlation not imply causation ? Why does correlation not imply causation and what does * correlation * and * causation * mean exactly ? Please explain like I'm five.

question: Can you please dumb down entropy for me ? I 'm a junior chemical engineering student . I 've taken and passed physical chemistry , thermodynamics and a bunch of other class like it , but this concept still fucking eludes me . Please explain like I'm five.
responses: It 's just probability . Consider all the possible outcomes of tossing a hundred coins , and make a histogram for number - of - heads . Obviously there 's precisely one outcome for 0 or 100 heads , 100 outcomes for 1 or 99 heads ... and ramping exponentially up to squillions of combinations with 50 heads . Take a given layout of 100 coins on a table , thwack the table with your fist to make coins jump in the air , and you 're pretty much guaranteed that your random change will result in N getting closer to 50 , rather than closer to 0 or 100 . Now repeat the same experiment with hot and cold molecules in a glass of water . There 's a hell of a lot more ways for them to be more or less evenly distributed than there are for them to be separated . As they do the Brownian Shake , the intermixedness is , statistically speaking , only going to increase . It 's a drunkard 's walk with steps Ω / ω high .

question: Why does a line have 1 dimension while a point has none ? If a line is made up of infinite points , why do we say that a line has 1 dimension while a point , by itself has zero ? Please explain like I'm five.
responses: An simple way to think about dimensions is how many length based measurements you can make . If you take a point , how many length based measurements can you make of it ? None . ( 0 ) If you take a line , you can measure its length . ( 1 ) If you take a square , you can measure its height and width . ( 2 ) If you take a cube , you can measure its height , width and depth . ( 3 ) If you take a Tardis , you can measure its height , width , depth and a point in time . ( 4 )

question: How do chinese people Alphabetize ? EDIT : Oh shit , I need to get bored in class more often . Please explain like I'm five.
responses: Long time lurker , first time poster . So let 's get started shall we ? I speak Mandarin as my second language , and am more familiar with the simplified version . There are two types of Mandarin : simplified and traditional . Trust me , the traditional version is much more convoluted than the simplified one . Firstly , in Mandarin , there is probably no equivalent of alphabetization , at least not in the conventional way . This is n't really surprising , since the characters descended from pictograms - images that convey a message . Thus , you can see that Mandarin characters more closely resemble pictures , rather than the normal alphabets that we see in English . Now then , how do we depict Mandarin characters ? Most simple characters consist of a left side and a right side . In some cases , both sides tell a story . For example , the character 话 is made up of 言(this is the traditional version of the left side ) and 舌 . The left tells us that this word is related to speech , since 言 means speech . The right is the character for the tongue . Put them together , and you get the character for the English equivalent of word . Speech from the tongue = word . Then again , it is n't always so simple . For some characters , only one side tells a story . I 'll take the example raised by /u / pudmedcentury . 姐 is made up of 女 and 且 . 女 tell us that this character is referencing to something feminine . However , as far as I know , 且 does not give any meaning to 姐 . For the record , 姐 means older sister , which addresses the feminine portion . Some characters operate in a different way - up and down . The character 烫 which means hot or scalded , is made up of 汤(soup ) and 火(fire ) . In the past , people probably got scalded by hot soup most frequently , leading to this character . Fire + soup = hot ( or if you are unlucky , scalded ) . There are many more orientations to Mandarin characters , including single words ( e.g. 人 which means person ) , top - left - right ( e.g. 森 which means forest ) , left - top - bottom ( e.g. 祸 which means disaster ) . As usual , some parts have meaning , some parts do n't ( as far as I know ) . There are just too many to list , and as such , I do n't think that Mandarin characters can be alphabetized in an English sort of way . How then do Mandarin dictionaries work ? Every character has a pronunciation , which is translated to English alphabets . So 森 is sen , 人 is ren , 烫 is tang . Basically , all the characters are arranged in alphabetical order , which makes the foundation of the dictionary . However , every translation normally has 4 tones . In Mandarin we call them 声(shēng ) , or sound . In speech , the 4 tones of the same translation sound different , with each tone having many characters . So 汤(tāng - first tone ) , 堂(táng - second tone ) , 躺(tǎng - third tone ) , 烫(tàng - fourth tone ) all sound different and have different meanings , 堂 , 糖 , 塘 , 膛 ( táng ) all sound the same , but have different meanings . Characters in dictionaries are first arranged by alphabets , and within same translations , arranged by tones . This is probably the closest that we have to alphabetization in Mandarin . There are many more aspects to Mandarin , like the fifth tone ( ü ) and the sequence to writing Mandarin characters . This is an incredibly complex language to learn with an incredibly large amount of vocabulary . Feel free to ask any questions or correct any mistakes that I made , or even to ask for the meaning of any characters that I used .

question: Why is n't it considered corruption when politicians grant access to lobbyists in return for financial gain . EDIT : Since lobbyists give campaign donations and receive access to politicians in return , why is n't this considered corruption ? Please explain like I'm five.
responses: Short answer : it depends on the country . I try to answer this without bringing my own opinion into it : Most countries have some forms you could ( depending on your opinions ) call legal corruption . For example : some democracies have non - professional parliaments - that means that the law - makers have their own job and business and only go to the parliament twice a year or so ( Switzerland would be an example for such a system ) . This means , of course , that these politicians have economical interests . You could argue , that this is some kind of corruption , since these guys will vote for their interests . On the other hand , people who vote them into the parliament know this . A teacher might vote for another teacher and a farmer for another farmer - since they know they will have roughly the same interests . In the US it is legal to donate for political campaigns - but you have to do so un - anonymously . So you are free to see , who finances Obama and who finances Romney . So the idea would be , that you could look up the donators which would tell you , which interests the politician will represent . This is true for most countries and most countries regulate this process in some forms .

question: What makes scientists think that there is more than three dimensions ? And how is time considered the fourth dimension ? Please explain like I'm five.
responses: We can observe one dimension ( a point ) , two dimensions ( a line ) , three dimensions ( a prism ) , and can just as easily mathematically represent four , five , six , etc , all the way up to infinite dimensional objects . Our eyes and brains are only calibrated to see up to three dimensions ( arguably consciousness allows us to perceive time as a fourth ) , but through math we can show that higher dimensions exist . Some incredibly complex math and physics problems have only been solved ( so far , at least ) by using more than three dimensions .

question: Why is it socially acceptable to eat donuts for breakfast , but not ice cream ? Donuts are basically fried cake , so why ca n't we eat ice cream for breakfast with them ? Please explain like I'm five.
responses: This is something of a shaky and potted history but in roughly 18th Century Europe , the entire structure of the day was different and what we would now eat at breakfast time would be a high - carbohydrate snack between the work you did in the early morning and the work you did in the early afternoon , thus it made sense to have a small pastry with your coffee , the croissant being a prime example . European immigration led to the trend going overseas and it slowly became part of American culture and integrated into having doughnuts for breakfast . So essentially , it 's founded in a tradition and whilst ice cream does make as much sense , you could n't dip it in your coffee in a French or Italian coffee bar in 1740 .

The concept of universal grandmothering and grandfathering became essential for a kingroup over time . This practice solidified their second generation versus this age group still having children that would outcompete their childrens children . As somebody already stated , the fact that men can still pass genome , with younger women , at older age still ensures basic survival incase of a severe calamity . Passing genome to older women who might not survive the rearing years with the child does nothing for the kin group . Let 's remember , the average life expectancy of humans up until modern medicine was quite low . So a woman going out of fertility at 40 was relatively considered older .

question: how are unpaid internships still legal ? I know universal just got sued because of this . But how , even for credit ( which most people have to pay for ) , is this practice still legal . Please explain like I'm five.
responses: It mostly is n't . As other commenters have said , but I will sum up : In the United States in order for an " employer " to legally have you on unpaid , you must either be a volunteer or a trainee . There is a strict test from the department of labor on what it means to be legally an unpaid trainee , which almost no real - life unpaid interns actually meet . You can find it [ here ] ( URL_0 ) along with friendly explanations . To be a volunteer , it is unclear what the precise boundaries are , but there are certain rules such as : * You ca n't " volunteer " for profit - generating work at a for - profit company . * It is illegal for an employer to have you volunteer to do something you were formerly paid for , or are sometimes paid for ( they ca n't pay you for 20 hours and have you work for 40 , and claim the other 20 are " volunteering " ) . * It is illegal for them to condition receipt of a job on " volunteering " for them first . So , the follow - up to your question is , given that most unpaid internship programs are actually illegal , why are they still so prevalent ? Here are some answers . * There 's no " internship cops " running around policing them . In order to be held illegal , they must be challenged . * Many people take these internships because they believe it will help get them recommendations , references , networking , etc . , in order to find a job . All of that gets shot to hell if you file a complaint . Most people would rather tolerate 4 months of unpaid work than have their career prospects . * Most interns do n't know they are illegal , ( reasonably ) figuring that if they are so prevalent they must be legal . Many small employers are also in this situation . Large employers like Fox Searchlight probably know it 's illegal but think they can get away with it . To those answering something like " it 's my time , I can do what I want with it " : * Nobody would be punishing interns , they 'd punish employers . * Illegal internship programs undermine the market for paid work , and undercut laws like the minimum wage . * Few people really * * want * * to work for no pay . They work for no pay because they think it will help their employment prospects later . The Fair Labor Standards Act is supposed to prevent employers from making unpaid work a grudgingly accepted prerequisite to a paid career . If it were properly enforced , it would . * Unpaid internships are classist , because only already - wealthy people can afford to work for no pay in order to break into a field . * Unpaid internships are racist and sexist , because unpaid interns are not covered by the employment provisions in the Civil Rights Act . This means that employers are free to racially discriminate against or sexually harass their unpaid interns ( in most states ) .

question: What is cultural appropriation and why is it bad ? Is white people rapping considered cultural appropriation ? Edit : And why is it that people say that it is a bad thing ? Please explain like I'm five.
responses: It 's a fuzzy concept . Cultural appropriation generally occurs when someone from a position of privilege ( like white people in the US ) pick and choose elements of other groups to incorporate in their life because they are " cool " or " exotic " . This is generally done in a way that is not respectful towards the culture where those elements originated . For example : a fashion photo shoot with white models wearing Native American headdresses . The cultural element is taken out of context and used to convey an idea of wilderness or perhaps mystique because that is how a lot of people think of native People and their customes . Another example is western people wearing a bindi when they go clubbing . The key element is that these other cultures / groups have to give up a lot of their way of being ( be it clothes or way of speaking or something else ) to fit into mainstream society ( " do n't speak like a black person if you want a job " , " you should wear western wear at the office ) which is basically designed around the most privileged group . Picking and choosing elements of other cultures because they are cool and then taking them out of context to promote your edginess is bad , learning about cultural elements in context and in a way that is respectful towards others is not . But then again it is a fine line , and not a topic where you can say " but ... in this case it 's okay " and prove any kind of point .

question: Why winking at a mirror while wearing 3D glasses turns one lens black . Discovered this a while back and I 've gotten nothing but " huh that 's weird " from my friends and family . " Please explain like I'm five.
responses: 3D glasses work by presenting each of your eyes with a different image . Modern 3D glasses do this by being polarized . Specific , they use [ circular polarization ] ( URL_0 ) , which has only two directions , clockwise and counterclockwise . A polarized lens will only let through light that is polarized in the same direction . So to make the 3D effect work , one lens is clockwise - polarized , and one is counterclockwise - polarized . That lets them project two overlapping imaged on the screen at once , with the light for each image polarized to match the lens that its intended to be visible through . This means that the light for the image intended for your right eye will pass through the right lens , but be blocked by the left lens , and vice versa for the other eye . Ambient light is not polarized , but rather consists of lots of different photons that are all vibrating in many different ways . Some of this light will be blocked by the lenses in your glasses , and some will pass through them . The light that passes through a polarized lens will be only the light that matches the lens 's polarization , meaning that , when light passes through a polarized lens , the light coming out the other side only consists of light vibrating in the same direction : i.e. * it 's polarized * . So when you look in the mirror and close one eye , the light bouncing off your face on the closed - eye side passes through the lens on that side and becomes polarized . It then bounces off the mirror and toward your open eye , which is behind a lens that is polarized opposite from the opposite lens , and opposite from the light coming through that lens . And thus the light passing through the opposite lens is blocked , and it looks black .

question: College admission essays . What are the best school looking for in essays / personal statements ? Explain like I'm five.
responses: Writing a successful college essay is 20 % writing skill / style , 20 % topic , and 60 % avoiding a mine field of cliches and phrases that will just piss your admissions officer off . Step 1 : Figure out what you 're good at . Pick three of these things . I 'll use myself as an example . I picked telling stories , writing lyrically , and soccer . Step 2 : Figure out what you enjoy . I picked listening to the radio , riding in the car , and New York City . Step 3 : The anecdote . Mine your personal history for something that combines at least 4 of these elements . It just has to be a glimmer of a memory . Mine was about driving around NYC on Passover listening to the baseball on the radio . Step 4 : ELABORATE . Write a full page describing everything you can about that memory . Step 5 : Edit step 4 . You 're going to want to cut that down to half a page . Step 6 : Jazz it up with something impressive . Ever had an internship ? Successfully interacted with an adult ? Read a cool book in an interesting way ? Relate that to your experience . * * You do n't have to discover the meaning of life but figure out some way that these things you like , things you 're good at , and experiences you have make you into someone that these people want on their campus . If they read your essay and feel like they could n't stand to be in a room with you for an hour , you 've done something wrong . * * tl;dr do n't come off like a prick . Step 7 : Make this fit onto one page . The margins do n't have to be crazy but if they do n't have to flip the page they do n't have that split second to realize how much you suck . Step 8 : Show it to people . You 're guidance counselor , your mom , your favorite english teacher , your best friend . They will give you advice . Feel free to ignore it but listen to what they have to say . If all of these people say you sound like a brown - nosed dick , you 've done something wrong . Step 9 : * * Put it down and focus on the other smaller elements of the application . * * When I met my admissions officer after I had been admitted to my top choice she said the main thing she remembered about my application was my list of books I had read recently . Step 10 : The step of don'ts . * * DO NOT * * talk about how a book that 's common on school reading lists changed your life ( Catcher in the Rye , Macbeth , Pride and Prejudice , Jane Eyre , The Scarlet Letter- these are essay killers . ) * * DO NOT * * write about that time you were in a car accident or that time you scored the winning goal or that time you hated high school ( note : if there is honestly something like a trauma that has affected your life significantly write a short piece about this and put it in the additional materials section . If your entire family died in a car crash and you had to switch schools and your grades dipped , the admissions people should know about it . ) * * DO NOT * * write about how hard it is to write this essay or about procrastination * * DO NOT * * write a witty , non - narrative , post - structuralist ode ( unless it 's great ) .

question: Could some explain to me like I 'm 5 exactly what cancer is and why we get it ? Do other species get cancer ? Why is it so common ? How long has cancer been around for ? Thanks ! Explain like I'm five.
responses: Many other species get cancer just like humans ; this includes ( but is nt limited to ) cats , dogs , horses , fish , birds and hamsters . The reason why it is so common is most likely due to a couple of things : One , humans live for a long time compared to most other animals . This means that our cells have to make LOTS of copies , which means that there is more chance for there to be a bad copy . Another reason is that humans expose themselves to a lot of bad things , that many animals in the wild do not . This can be radiation from your microwave , eating too much unhealthy food , smoking cigarettes , some special medicines or even the liquid we use to clean our dishes ! Cancer has probably been around for as long as there have been life with more than one cell ( a multicellular organism ) - some ancient Egyptians even had cancer !

question: - > Big O Notation No matter what i read or how many people explain it to me I still do n't quite get what on earth this is ! Explain like I'm five.
responses: An algorithm is a way to solve a problem . One problem could be to find the number with the lowest value in a list of numbers . The big - O notation tells you how the time taken * O ( ) * by the algoritm relates to the size * n * of the problem : * Lets say our algoritm ( method ) of finding the lowest value in a list , is by going through each element in the list , comparing it to the previous smallest number . If a value is smaller than the previous number , we remember it . And so on . So we use this algorithm on a list of numbers that is 50 numbers long . Afterwards we use the algorithm on a list of numbers that is twice as long . How much more time will it take to use the algorithm ? * This algorithm will take twice as long . * We can see that : ( size of problem x 2 ) will take ( time of solution x 2 ) In general for this algorithm : If we make the problem n times larger , * * the time to solve will become * n * times larger * * . The bold text here translates to a big - O notation of O(***n * * * ) .

question: explain the Birthday Paradox to me . i saw it on io9 today , and while i vaguely understand the math , and i understand the end result , it still does n't make sense to me . can someone explain it ? Explain like I'm five.
responses: Lets make this simpler : if you only had 1 person , then there is a 0 % chance that two people can share the same birthday right ? ( I know this is obvious , but the first thing you need to do is let go of the idea that the number of people equals the number of chances for having a match ) . now , two people means that there is one chance , because , there is only one pair to consider , but what happens if you have 3 people , lets call them Bob , John and Alice . Bob and John make one pair , Bob and Alice make another pair , and John and Alice make 3 pairs . By adding one person , our probabilities jumped from 1/365 to 3/365 . Lets add one more , now we have Bob , John , Alice and Sarah , lets count the pairs : Bob and John , Bob And Alice , Bob And Sarah , John and Alice , John and Sarah , and Alice and Sarah . So by adding one more person , the number of possible pairs that have a chance of sharing the same birthday , jumped from 3 in 365 to 6 in 365 . If this is still confusing , just try adding more and more people , you ll notice that every person has to be checked against every other person , not just individually .

question: the distinction between a musical key , mode and scale I get that they 're all related , but I do n't quite understand when / why you 'd use one term instead of another . Explain like I'm five.
responses: [ Great music dictionary online . ] ( URL_0 ) The terms you 're asking about are often used interchangeably . There are however , specifics to consider : A scale is essentially a collection of notes in some kind of logical order . There are many possible scales , each with their own unique musical flavour . " Key " ( from Dolmetsch ): specific scales or series of notes defining a particular * tonality * , for example , certain keys may , on the basis of the sequence of successive intervals , be defined as major or minor and are then named after their tonic or key note Modes are ALMOST like scales ( in that they are more or less scales ) but are treated in their own special context . If we are in the * * key * * of A Major , we might play notes from the A Major * * scale * * . However , depending on the harmonic context , we may choose not to think " tonally " . For instance , if we 're playing a ii - V progression ( ad infinitum ) in A Major , we 're in " modal " harmonic territory . When improvising or writing in this context , it 's likely you would use B Dorian and E Mixolydian * * scales * * . These two scales have the exact same notes as an A Major scale ; they just start and end on notes other than the tonic ( B and E respectively ) . Because of this , they are referred to as * * modes * * of the A Major scale . They share the same notes , but are applied in their own unique manner . It 's also possible to hear a minor / major key referred to as a minor / major mode if the harmony is modal . Modal music has chord progressions that are characteristic of a certain mode and does not have any " tonal " references ( i.e. perfect cadences , tonicizations , etc . ) .

question: Major Depression I am curious what depression is , the actual effects on the body , why it exists , like I 'm 5 please :) Explain like I'm five.
responses: When bad things happen , people sometimes respond by being sad . Sadness is usually a good thing . Even though it 's not fun to be sad , being sad makes people reflect about the consequences of the bad thing that happened and , when they start to not be sad any more , prepare for new courses of action . If no one ever got sad , they would have high levels of energy even when they should be withdrawing to think about their lives . Depression happens when the sadness does n't go away , and people become unable to prepare for new courses of action . They start to become numb and entirely withdraw from the world around them . The sadness that was initially good takes over their lives . Some people are more likely to stay sad than others because they lack certain chemicals in their brain . Other people are more likely to stay sad because they had so many bad things happen to them that they ca n't get past their big sadness . Some people can help get over their sadness by talking to a person called a " therapist . " Therapists are really good listeners and help people talk through their sadness instead of hiding from it like many people try to do . But some people who have a lot of depression need special medicines that help increase the brain 's access to important chemicals that regulate energy and feelings of well - being . These medications can help people overcome their sadness .

question: Sine , Cosine , Tangent , Secant , Cosecant , & Cotangent . I apologize if this is more suited for AskReddit ; I just need help understanding these functions as an idea instead of a bunch of associative memorized words and numbers . Explain like I'm five.
responses: Look at [ this triangle ] ( URL_0 ) . Take the " 1 " and replace it with an " r " , which is the radius of the circle . The " x " and " y " should be obvious to you or you 're screwed . That thing that looks like a screwed up 8 is a theta , that 's the angle between the x - axis and the radius . Sin(theta ) = y / r Cos(theta ) = x / r Tan(theta ) = y / x Cosecant(theta ) = 1 / sin(theta ) Secant(theta ) = 1 / cos(theta ) Cotangent(theta ) = 1 / tan(theta ) I remember this all by recognizing that none of this makes any sense . Sin(theta ) versus Cos(theta ) . Sine , cosine . Should be x , y. Instead is y , x. Tan(theta ) . Should be x / y , instead is y / x. Cosecant(theta ) should be 1 / cosine(theta ) . Instead it 's 1 / sine(theta ) . Secant(theta ) should be 1 / sine(theta ) . Instead it 's 1 / cosine(theta ) . Cotangent(theta ) should not be 1 / tan(theta ) , because everything else is wrong , but it is in fact 1/ tan(theta ) .

question: First grade math Prove to me that 2 + 2=4 , and not 5 . On the surface it 's obvious , but as the cliche goes , " prove it . " Or prove other first grade math . Explain like I'm five.
responses: You can even keep it simple by doing something like : 2 + 2 = 4 ( 1 + 1 ) + ( 1 + 1 ) = ( 1 + 1 + 1 + 1 ) This is by definition . now , associative property 1 + 1 + 1 + 1 = 1 + 1 + 1 + 1 These two terms are clearly the same . To be very rigorous , you need to use " Peano arithmetic " 2 + 2 = 2 + S1 = S(2 + 1 ) = S(2 + S0 ) = S(S(2 + 0 ) ) = S(S(2 ) ) //2 is defined as S(S(0 ) ) = S(S(S(S(0 ) ) ) = 4 //SSSS0 = 4 by definition Where S is a special function that gives the successor of a number . And addition is defined by two ( recursive ) relation : a + 0 = a a + Sb = S(a+b )

question: how " the exception proves the rule " I hear this usually when people are arguing and I have never understood how that works that a rule is proven to be correct by providing an example of said rule not working . Explain like I'm five.
responses: This phrase , when taken very literally , is technically incorrect . However , it 's usually used in cases where the exceptions are rare and difficult to find , which proves that the rule works in the vast majority of situations . Example : Newtonian physics are technically incorrect , as they break down once you get into outer space shit . However , the fact that you have to look to space to find exceptions proves that Newtonian physics work in almost all practical , everyday situations . question: - What does " shorting a stock " mean ? Someone told me this morning that they " shorted " netflix for 285 . Can anyone explain this ? Explain like I'm five.
responses: Shorting is essentially buying a negative share of a stock . So if I shorted 1 share of Netflix at 285 , my broker gives me $ 285 , but I owe them the share . I also have to typically pay interest on the $ 285 . So , what does this get me ? Let 's say sometime in the future , Netflix hits 200 . I can " sell " my short by buying a share and giving it back to my broker . The deal is done , and I get to keep the $ 85 difference , less interest . So , why would n't you want to do this ? Well , if Netflix rebounds and reaches 400 , I still owe a share . I 'd either have to fork out $ 400 to get out , or keep paying interest indefinitely .

question: Terminal Velocity Why ca n't objects keep accelerating why do they hit a terminal velocity . Explain like I'm five.
responses: Air is a physical substance . Physical substances invoke reactions against actions . Gravity pulls you down . That 's an action . When the force of gravity has pulled you so that the reaction the air has on your body is equal to the rate at which gravity is pulling against you ( acceleration of 9.8 meters per second per second ) , you 've hit terminal velocity . You can not speed up without reducing wind resistance .

question: How to properly do laundry . I 've never been able to confront this because of the sheer risk of ruining my clothes . But the time has come and I MUST learn . I 've read some articles online , but none have really helped . Explain like I'm five.
responses: Assuming you know how to physically work a washer and dryer , it 's more about what you * do n't * do . * Do n't combine deep or bright colors ( reds in particular ) with whites or light colors , or they 'll bleed and ruin your whites . Combining different dark colors ( a dark red and a dark blue shirt , for instance ) is generally fine . * Hotter water gets your clothes cleaner but makes the colors more likely to bleed . Personally , the only clothes I wash in hot water are socks and white undershirts ( in the same load ) and jeans . Stick with cold water for anything made of wool , anything with both light and dark colors ( striped shirt , for instance ) , and delicates . Warm is fine for just about anything else . * Hang up sweaters and delicates to dry if possible ; if not , dry with low or no heat . Medium heat is fine for anything else . Keep the lint trap ( usually just inside the door near the bottom ) as clean as possible .

question: The Great Digg Migration  . I 've seen this phrase several times , concerning a movement of users from " URL_0 " to reddit . Why and what happened ? Explain like I'm five.
responses: The issues were highly complex , in the end , Digg was started as a " get rich quick " scam where they had investors bring in about 70 mil to start the site . They hired like 50 people to run / design the site and then their investors were like " where the fuck is our money ? " when the site was not profitable . This chase for profits led them astray from enriching the user experience and towards grabbing for cash any way possible , including sponsored links and whatnot . This was called " Version 4 " which was basically more or less an entire re - write . What else did they do ... Oh , stories could n't be buried , since they wanted to embrace some sort of hippy culture where there 's no negativity , just like facebook . And they fired their CEO . And Kevin rose tookover and plowed it into the ground even more . Basically , a huge CF related to investors and them taking money which they never should 've gotten . Which was all part of Kevin Roses plan anyway . It seems most business models kind of go like this : Be an internet celebrity / attract a lot of attention . Help rich folk / investors part with their money by giving you their money under the auspices that you are using it to find a company to turn $ X into $ X + $ Y. Remove money from company in the form of salary / subsistence and hope to some day go public where you can really cash in . Retire , not giving 2 fucks whether your contribution to society was positive or not , just revel in the money . People in this class of " entrepeneur " : Kevin Rose Michael Arrington Gizmodo guys you know the lot of them . cult of personality types , attention whores . nothing really of any use . Just an audience and really really bad ideas that other people think are good enough to throw money at .

question: ELI 5 : The comic the kid is reading in the movie Watchmen . I did n't really get it so can someone explain what the ending of the comic meant Explain like I'm five.
responses: Ooh ! Ooh ! I 'm credible on this one ! It 's a story about an Englishmen who gets trapped on a secluded coastal shelf Robin Crusoe - style . After a bit he finds his crew - mates corpses start floating around , bloated . He 's afraid of a pirate ship that is going off to raid his home town , the same pirate ship that sunk his boat in the beginning . Fighting with himself morally , he ties up his crew - mates bloated stinking corpses and sails home . During this time he kills a shark , though that may be reflective of the events in Watchmen itself , it 's largely irrelevant in the comic at the time . When he comes home he finds the town in a state that would suggest they had all been taking captive by the pirate ship . He suddenly comes to believe the entire town has made a horrible degrading deal with the pirates , or that the townsfolk now * are * pirates . In a fit of panic and rage , he kills a young couple riding through the night on a horse . He takes the horse and rides home , and then accidentally kills one of his family members , mistaking them for pirates . He realizes that in a sense he now sort of is a pirate himself , and this drives him mad . He goes completely gazonkers and begins swimming to the pirate ship , which was only now even approaching the town . The end . In a way it 's all sort of reflective of the things happening with the characters in the novel , the upcoming war , and the people of New - York at the time . I 'm pretty sure this is now my longest comment ever .

question: Some American political terminology I 'm English and there is a lot American political terminology I do n't understand . Can anyone explain the following to me ? senator , governor , congressman , representative , Explain like I'm five.
responses: At the Federal level and the State level , government is broken into 3 branches : Judicial , Legislative , Executive . The 50 states will all elect a governor to head the state 's executive branch . They will also elect 2 Senators to the Federal Senate ( somewhat analogous to your House of Lords , but with real power ) to 6 year terms , and several Representatives to the House of Representatives ( somewhat analogous to your House of Commons ) to 2 year terms . Representatives are voted on not statewide , but district wide . Each state is broken into several districts based on population distribution ( as well as political hackery - this is known as " gerrymandering " ) and you can only vote for the district - wide Representative race . The general idea , and something that is * generally * true is that the Senate is supposed to be a place of moderate statesemen types - more conservative ( not necessarily politically Conservative , but conservative as to be not constantly swayed by ever changing public opinion ) and more experienced . The House is basically a rabid , reactionary dog fight . Every states also has its own state legislature , though it varies a little bit . Most have a Senate and a House , but some are called different things and Nebraska only has one house ( called the Legislature ) . In order for new legislation to pass , it is generally true to say it has to pass both the House and the Senate . The truth , as always , is much more complicated and convoluted .

question: How does Reddit Enhancement Suite know the exact number of upvotes and downvotes a comment receives ? Is it an algorithm that does an estimate of sorts ? Or are those numbers actually 100 % accurate ? How does it work ? Explain like I'm five.
responses: The only TRUE number that reddit provides is the difference between the upvotes and the downvotes . For any submission or comment , at any given time , you can never know for sure the total votes , upvotes , or the downvotes . These numbers are faked just because when reddit admins originally removed them ( to help with spam ) , people complained that they 'd rather see fake numbers than no numbers .

question: Imaginary numbers Please explain why and how did mathematicians arrive at the conclusion that imaginary numbers exist . Explain like I'm five.
responses: Does the number two exist ? Sure you can imagine two cats , or two forks , or whatever , but does two exist , outside of being an adjective applied to nouns ? What about the number pi ? It is n't even possible to have pi of anything ! The question is purely philosophical , but you should approach the complex numbers with the same mentality . We accept a concept of two and ignore the question of " two what ? " because the question is irrelevant , we can say wonderful things about two independent of the answer . Just like that , we can say wonderful things about 3 + 7i , regardless of whether you can actually have that many cats . The reason mathematicians came up with the complex numbers is because it is often convenient to consider them , if just as a means to a real end . For instance , there is a [ formula ] ( URL_0 ) for the roots of a cubic polynomial involving complex numbers , such a formula is impossible to write without using them , even if all the roots are real . They are in a very precise sense the natural completion of the real numbers because all polynomials of degree n have n roots in the complex numbers . This property is called algebraically complete , and the complex numbers are the only " algebraic " extension of the real numbers which satisfy it . In an entirely different direction , the theory of complex analysis , essentially calculus over the complex numbers , is very powerful and has innumerable applications .

question: Why restaurants do not like to split bills for tables . Why do n't restaurants like to split bills for tables ? Is it a POS thing ? Something else ? Explain like I'm five.
responses: Could be : 1 ) Manager overrides are needed to do it on certain systems ( To keep people from splitting drinks which is a way of printing a check to make it look like the full total , then keeping the extra cash given and " using " the drinks on the next tab ) . 2 ) People are moving around like crazy on a big party and it 's really hard to keep track ESPECIALLY if there are multiple servers on the same party ( No POS I 've seen allows multiple servers to use the same check , though most bartenders can ) so many , many checks will usually lead to a check getting " dropped " or not paid for . Which also leads to ... 3 ) Putting together a book only takes 30 seconds ( Taking the check with payment inside , finding the specific check , running the card / doing the cash work , setting it back together to deliver ) . But that 30 seconds divided by 20 people is a long time of just moving books . And there is ALWAYS someone who " has to leave right this second . " 4 ) Some POS systems " lock " checks that are mid payment ( I 'm looking at you , Squirrel ) . Easiest way to explain that is I have table 204 split into six checks . Someone wanted their check before anyone else , so I processed their credit card first . Now they 're sitting there talking with the book under their hand and I 'm completely locked out of entering in any other orders until the original has been processed and cleared . These are just some random reasons that pop up . Long story short it 's not impossible by any stretch of the imagination , but it IS going to end up taking the server away from waiting on you for quite some time in any case . The long story short , yes of course we 'll accommodate you . But we 're only trying to talk you out of it so we can give you better service , not to make our lives easier . Lets face it , we only make money when the service is good .

question: What Happens to Debt After You Die ? What 's to stop someone from running up a whole bunch of debt before the kick the bucket ? Is it really fair to put that on the spouse and/or kids ? Explain like I'm five.
responses: It depends on the terms of the debt agreement . But typically , it will be applied against your estate , which means your debts must be settled before your assets can be passed along to your heirs . There is nothing to stop a dying person from running up debts . It may not be " fair " to hold their survivors responsible , but it more fair than holding the lenders responsible . question: Transubstantiation in Catholicism and why they believe it I can not fathom that an adult thinks he can turn wine and crackers into flesh and blood with a few magic words . Maybe I 'm misunderstanding something ... Explain like I'm five.
responses: What is transubstantiation ? Let 's break it down . Trans - obviously to change . Substance - that which stands under . In the time the word " transubstantiation " was formed , the word substance was not " physically touchable stuff " but " essential nature , " i.e. that which stands under the physical object , that facet of being which lies under the purely physical . So what does it mean to transubstantiate ? It should be obvious - to change the internal nature of some object , i.e. to alter its essential being in some way . Not to change the physical nature of the object , but to change the being which that physical body delimits . This is of course an old conception of being which is n't the same as the modern " everything is just particles , " but if you accept any dualist thought it 's pretty easy to see where transubstantiation can make sense . If you just think about one of the shitty paradoxes where if you replace the hilt of a sword then replace the blade is it still that thing , you can see where this sort of being fits naturally into what humans think . Basically , the modern conception of being equates it with extancy . The old Catholic sense of being also allows for the concept of substancy .

question: What is defragging my hard drive , and how will it help my computer ? This is probably a stupid question , but I know nothing about computers . Explain like I'm five.
responses: hard drives contain 2 key parts : 1)read /write head : a sometimes magnetized pin that can move left and right . 2 ) platter : a metallic disk that holds the data . you can visualize the data with this simple analogy . imagine you have a very long thin glass tabletop . now pour tiny metallic shards in a straight line . hold a strong magnet over a small region of the long thin line of metallic shards . those metallic shards will stand up . they will stay standing up even after you remove the magnet . you just created a 1 ; create more 1s by you moving left and right at regular intervals . To make that 1 a 0 simply put the magnet on the underside of the glass table and the metallic shards will fall back in line with the rest of the shards . The glass table and the metal shards are the platter . You and your magnet are the read / write head . Crudely that is how a hard drive stores data . What does storing data on a hard drive have to do with defragging ? I thought you would never ask ! lets continue . When you store a file on your hard drive . That read / write head asks the filesystem to give it a spot on your platter to make a series of 1 and 0 to represent the file you want to write . When you want to read that file again the read / write head must lookup the location of the file in the filesystem(like a table of contents for the platter and outside the scope of this explanation ) . The filesystem then tells the read / write head what part or parts of the platter to go to to retrieve the file . Seems simple . Hard drives likes to put things in order just like you would if you had a 20 foot long glass table top with metal shards . Would n't you like to have that term paper you wrote in order when you went to retrieve it ? Or would you like to walk back and forth several times across your long thin table to get the term paper retrieved in the correct order ? That term paper would be worthless if the words were out of order . That is how you would obviously start . The term paper is in order , next you stop for the night and save some funny pictures on reddit and store that on your glass table with metal shards ( hard drive ) . You left some space to finish the term paper . So your good right ? The paper goes longer than expected ( rare I know ) but you add a works cited page and whatnot . Ok you ran out of space to retrieve that term paper in order . Now half the term paper is at that start of your hard drive ( glass table ) and the other half is near the end of the table . When you want to read /write to that term paper you have to keep track of 2 sections of that table . And walk double the distance . Hard drives ( or you with your magnet ) will will take longer to retreive files when they have to move all over the place to retrieve a file . Or for that matter a series of files commonly accessed at the same time . TL;DR – a fragmented hard drive is when the drive is no longer storing directories , files common accessed at the same time , or even single files in linear order . Its chopped up – fragmented . Defragging puts these commonly accessed files in a physically closer location location to each other . This reduces the actual distance the read write head must move .

question: The difference in terms " Latino " and " Hispanic " While listening to the radio , it seems like these two phrases are interchangeable , but I do n't want to assume . What is the difference ? Explain like I'm five.
responses: Hispanic - The term Hispanic was first adopted by the US in the early 1970s as a " classification " under the US Census to group together all individuals with Spanish Speaking origins . As you can see , this can include anything from Peru to Mexico , Cuba , ect ... and even contains Spain and Portugal . Latino / a - This has to do more with one 's ethnic background , although still tied to a traditionally Spanish speaking country . In 1997 the US Government began using both " Latino " and " Hispanic " interchangeably to classify people from this particular ethnic background . Both of these " classifications " do not consider race . Just in Mexico alone , one can be Black or White and still be considered Latino / Hispanic . This of course confused a lot of people . * * Extra * * : From a personal perspective I remember using the term Hispanic to identify myself up until the late 90 's . Later in life I began seeing a change in the way my peers would identify themselves as Latino . Being the conformist that I am I began to use that term for myself as well . Today I prefer to call myself Latino . * * TL;DR * * The government made up words to classify us and now we do n't even know which one to use .

Does that make them any less of a piece of work ? We grant people a limited term monopoly on their ideas because it allows them to make money , which encourages them and others to continue to create new works , for the benefit of society , not just the copyright owner . Lastly , the constitution dictates that copyrights should be limited term .

question: Why does a disk have to be defragmented ? What causes the files to " fragment " ? What is happening when the files are defragmented ? Explain like I'm five.
responses: Your hard disk writes as if it was putting books in a book shelf . When a program asks it to do something , it puts a bunch of books in the shelf . It fills the book shelf in a non - random left to right fashion to do it as quickly as possible . Later , a program might ask it to read the books in the shelf , to read a file . It can do this thousands of times a second . Your computer is built to do multiple things at once , and when two programs ask it to fill the book shelf at the same time , rather than doing the work for one program and then the next , it will attempt to do both things at once . This will cause all the books for all the different programs to get mixed together . This is fragmentation . When the books are all mixed , and a program asks the computer to read the books back to it , it has to take extra time to sort out the pertinent books . Fragmented files take longer to read and therefore cause the computer to become less efficient . When the files are defragmented , the computer takes time to sort the books in advance .

question: This 4D Cube I came across this image : URL_0 Can someone explain why this is " 4D " and not just a moving 3D object ? Explain like I'm five.
responses: If you start with a single point , you have a 0th dimension . To represent the 1st dimension you can plot another point , and connect the two points , making a line ( 1 dimension ) . Using the same idea , we can represet the 2nd dimension by drawing another line , and connecting the two end points of those lines to the two end points of the other line , and then we have a square plane ( 2 dimensions ) . Then we can go further and represent the 3rd dimension . This is done the same way by drawing another square plane , and connecting the points at each corner of the square plane , to the corners of the other square plane . We then have a cube of 3 dimensional space . Now this is the part where it becomes hard to visualize . The method of representing a higher dimension is the same . We draw another cube , and we connect all the corner points of that cube to our original cube , and we have created the shape in your animation ; a tesseract , or a " 4D cube " .

question: knots  in your back . What is their cause and what exactly happens ? Explain like I'm five.
responses: When you flex your muscle , you bring the two ends closer together , causing a bulge in the belly of the muscle . Most of the time , when you relax it , the muscle lengthens and smooths . Sometimes , if you put your body in one position often or long enough ( stress and repetitive movements are two of the biggest causes ) , the wrong position becomes a habit , and the muscles stay bulged . Those are knots . They can also happen when there is an injury . The muscles tighten , acting like a splint to save the body from further harm .

question: At what point does physics move from Classical Mechanics to Quantum Mechanics How small does something have to be for Quantum Mechanics to apply instead of Classical Mechanics ? Explain like I'm five.
responses: The answer must be approximate : quantum mechanics just applies less to larger things than it does to smaller things . In terms of particles , electrons have many interesting quantum mechanical interactions , but anything the size of an atom behaves pretty much classically . But this does n't mean that quantum effects ca n't matter , in aggregate , at very large scales . The photoelectric effect can involve an entire sheet of metal , but it was only successfully explained by quantum mechanics .

question: The Monty Hall problem [ URL_0 ] ( URL_0 ) I still do n't get it , do n't believe it . Explain like I'm five.
responses: You can do two things , either always stay or always change . The host will never reveal the car , instead he 'll always show you one of the shitty prizes . Let 's say you always stay : You pick door number 1 with the car , presenter shows either door , you stay and * * win . * * You pick door number 2 with the shitty prize , presenter shows you shitty prize behind door 3 , you stay and * * lose . * * You pick door number 3 with the shitty prize , presenter shows you shitty prize behind door 2 , you stay and * * lose . * * --- You pick door number 1 with the car , presenter shows either door , you chose to change and * * lose . * * You pick door number 2 with the shitty prize , presenter shows shitty prize behind door 3 , you chose to change and * * win . * * You pick door number 3 with the shitty prize , presenter shows shitty prize behind door 2 , you chose to change and * * win . * * --- When you always stay with your initial choice , the chance indeed is one in three , however if you change every time your chances go up to 2/3 .

question: Why something to the power of 0 is always 1 . Why is this ? A to the power of 0 is 1 . Why ? Explain like I'm five.
responses: The best way I found to think about it is like this : start with A^1 = A. A^2 is A * A. A^3 is A * A * A , ( or A^2 * A ) & so on . As you can see , each time you increase the power by 1 , you multiply by A again . In other words : A^n+1 = A^n * A. divide both sides by A & you get A^n = A^n+1 / A. If you let n=0 , you get A^0 = A^0 + 1 / A , which is A^0 = A^1 / A , which is A^0 = A / A , which is A^0 = 1 . So therefore , A^0 = 1 . * * * * * Edit : Bonus round for negative powers , if you 're interested . Now that we know A^0 = 1 we can do this : Using A^n = A^n+1 / A again . let n=-1 . A^-1 = A^-1 + 1 / A , which is A^-1 = A^0 / A , which is A^-1 = 1 / A. let n=-2 . A^-2 = A^-2 + 1 / A , which is A^-2 = A^-1 / A , which is A^-2 = ( 1 / A ) / A , which is A^-2 = 1 / A^2 This can be generalised to A^-n = 1 / A^n .

question: why the Japanese Empire invaded small islands during WW2 and did n't have a larger mainland campaign Watching The Pacific by HBO and wondering why the small islands were so important over larger islands or mainland accumulation . Explain like I'm five.
responses: It really depends on the point of view you 're looking at the war from . For Japan , the war started at least in 1937 ( the second Sino - Japanese War ) , and by that point they had taken Manchuria and Korea , and were fighting battles in mainland China regularly . When it came to war with the US , The Japanese knew that the US would win in a full out war , so they designed the attack on Pearl Harbor to be so shocking that the US would just negotiate an end to the oil embargo on Japan . But the opposite happened and the US went into full attack mode . The Japanese used many of the smaller island battles as a possible chance for the last big , bloody battle that would finally get the US to negotiate an end to the war . But FDR had put into place a policy of unconditional surrender - meaning there was never going to be any negotiation , no matter how bloody the battles got . Like u / TheSecretMe said , the islands were strategic gold . Once the US took Saipan , the war was essentially over - it gave the US an airbase that was close enough for the B29 to bomb regularly .

question: What or Who is a ' Circlejerk ' ? People keep mentioning this term all over reddit . I have no clue what it means . Explain like I'm five.
responses: Imagine a book club where people go in and discuss about books , what they liked / disliked , what could have been better , etc . Now , this book club has a lot of members , let 's say 1000 people who are gathered every week to talk about a specific book . What happens in that book club is that the majority voice its opinion in a few words : This book is good . The discussion just goes around why the book is good and what makes it so great . But anyone who goes against that opinion saying they dislike the book , thinking out their arguments and making their cases are frowned upon , and kicked out of the book club so that the " the book is good " discussions can go on , even if it does n't lead anywhere since there are virtually no debate going on . This is what a circlejerk is .

question: Who are the present owners of the $ 1 houses in Detroit , and why do n't they have the liabilities discussed in the answer to the other question ? Stole the idea for this question from /u / Xandari11 [ comment link ] ( URL_0 ) Explain like I'm five.
responses: It 's generally not illegal for an empty building to not be up to code . But in order to get a certificate of occupancy ( or whatever the equivalent is called in that jurisdiction ) the building would likely have to be brought up to code . It 's not illegal for the house to sit there , but if someone tried to live there , then it could be an issue . If the house was structurally unsound and deemed a danger to people just to be around , the current owners could potentially be cited for that . I 'm not sure that Detroit 's government is really in much of a position to be able going around writing tickets for that sort of thing . Also , often times , the owners of these sorts of houses are n't actually banks . They 're slum lords , many of whom likely do n't even live in the city . The local government would probably have a hard time tracking down the owners and citing them if they wanted to . This is also how many blighted homes end up owing back property taxes . I see similar issues a lot in New Orleans . It 's been a pretty big deal since Katrina , after which a lot of owners basically abandoned their flooded homes , and ignored anything from the city telling them to clean up their property . Eventually the city has managed to seize some of these properties , but that takes a lot of legal work , because the law is generally written to protect private property .

question: Why are boobs and butts attractive ? They 're just lumps of fat right ? Explain like I'm five.
responses: It 's really just sexual selection . This is a bit of a tough concept , but pretty much so long as a given feature is not a significant detriment to passing on your genes , practically any feature can become grossly exaggerated by a runaway self - perpetuating cycle . This is why female peacocks think ridiculous long tails on male peacocks are hot . That humans fixated on double rounded forms is probably originally arbitrary . ( And in modern humans is greatly cultural . ) Yes , a specific hip - to - waist ratio and a good layer of fat are indicators of female fertility , but boob and butt size and shape are pretty independent of those factors .

question: Why do we accelerate when falling ? It seems like a very basic concept , but is n't the gravitational force the same all the way to the ground ? Edit : Also , why do we stop accelerating at some point ? Explain like I'm five.

The force is being applied constantly , so you accelerate constantly . It may help to think of it in terms of a question that is essentially the same : " If I step on the gas , and keep the pedal down , why do I keep accelerating ? " The gravitational field is keeping the pedal down .

question: How does GPS work ? How does it know where you are ? Edit : Thanks for the replies now I understand how it works . Explain like I'm five.
responses: There are a large number of satellites that are used in GPS . Each of these satellites broadcasts a radio signal that has two pieces of information : the current time of the broadcast and the current location of the satellite . Your GPS device is basically a radio receiver . It listens to the radio signal that is sent out from the GPS satellites . Once it can receive a signal from multiple GPS satellites ( 4 is the minimum ) it can then perform the calculation to determine where you are . The calculation takes into account the position of the satellite , the time of the message , and also the distance from where you are to the satellite . The distance is determined by taking into account the fact that radio waves travel at the speed of light .

question: What is happening in Egypt ? And why is it happening ? Heard on the radio that the " Muslim Brotherhood " is storming gov't buildings . And that everyone is angry with the Egyptian Government and the American Government . No idea why or what started this . Explain like I'm five.
responses: What 's going on is a power struggle between two groups : 1 . The Military , who has run the country since the 1950s and is generally very well - liked by the Egyptian people . 2 . The Muslim Brotherhood , who have been operating in the country since the 1930s trying to establish an Islamist government ( one who governs according to the principles of Islam ) and enjoy a fair amount of support . Now , the military has been oppressing the Muslim Brotherhood for the better part of a century . Let 's just say old habits die hard . Dictator Hosni Mubarak was removed in 2011 by a popular revolt , supported by the Muslim Brotherhood , and eventually by the military also . They basically realized he was done and they would either go down with him or manage a transition to democracy where they were still in charge . This transition to democracy happened . Sort of . They had free and fair elections , and to the military 's dismay the Muslim Brotherhood was elected . Not a huge surprise considering they have a lot of popular support and they were the only opposition who was organized BEFORE this all happened . So Muhammed Morsi takes the reigns . Now remember , the MB have wanted this for like 70 years . He goes about trying to make the Islamist country they 've envisioned , against the wishes of a fair chunk of the population . He also behaves like a dictator , imprisoning opposition members and trying to consolidate his power to ensure the MB will run the place for a long time . So the military kicks him out with the support of basically all the non - MB Egyptians , and takes the reigns again . Now they are basically making sure the Muslim Brotherhood is never going to run the show again .

question: why ' Diplomatic Immunity ' is a thing . Why does this exist ? Why are family members covered ? Can I rob a bank and murder people like NCIS and Law and Order would lead you to believe ? Explain like I'm five.
responses: Family members are n't covered at all ; only diplomats that the host country agrees to accredit as official diplomatic representatives get immunity . What it means in practice is that countries agree not to prosecute each other 's diplomats for breaking local laws . The host country can ask for this privilege to be waived , which sometimes happens . The point is that diplomacy wo n't work if diplomats are bound by local laws . Imagine if Canada appointed a female ambassador to Saudi Arabia , and she got arrested for driving . It 's not a get out of jail free card though . Several years ago , a Russian diplomat killed someone here in Canada while driving drunk . Canada asked the Russians to waive immunity , but they decided to try him in Russia instead . Russian prisons being what they are , he 'd probably have preferred to be prosecuted here ...

question: why do we think we need to go to war with Syria when no one else has our back ? Edit : thanks for the responses ! I hope more chime in on the matter with their takes . Explain like I'm five.
responses: Well , there are the " official " reasons which probably do n't need summarizing because they are all over the news . The " real " reasons ca n't be known for sure because we do n't have access to internal government records , but there are several high profile foreign policy think tanks which look at this stuff in depth from the US governments perspective . One of the perspectives that has emerged is that it is actually in the US and Israeli interest ( for a number of reasons that need much more backstory ) if the civil war continues at a low boil over a number of years . Since the Assad regime has gained a clear upper hand over the last few months , a US led action of some sort might be able to erase the Assad advantage and allow the war to fall back into a stalemate . Another perspective is more in line with " mainstream " justifications . In particular , Obama took a risk by so boldly putting forward the idea of the " red line " as a way to bound or control the parameters of the conflict without direct involvement . If clear evidence exists that his " red line " has been crossed , then the administration feels it must take some action to " maintain credibility " . My opinion is that it is some combination of both of the above perspectives . It certainly is n't because the US feels a need to act forcefully against the use of chemical weapons . Even a quick look at the US 's history in the region over the last couple of decades has shown a recurring willingness to look the other way when allies make use of chemical weapons .

question: Why do n't websites allow spaces as characters in usernames and passwords ? I do n't understand why an underscore_is an appropriate character to use , but a space is n't . Why ca n't I use any character my computer can type as a password character ? Explain like I'm five.
responses: A lot of database servers trim starting and ending whitespace in a variety of datatypes and circumstances and it can be used maliciously in usernames . Consider your username : MrsIvestermcbean it 's impossible to discern from these different usernames by most people : MrsIvestermcbean MrsIvestermcbean even without them , I could probably get 2 or 3 of your friends tricked with the username : MrsIvesterrncbean For passwords , there 's also a ton of places you can run into trouble by allowing spaces , even if you 're hashing . A lot of frameworks , and browsers would have problems with a password like ` " " ` , a lot of database operations may trim " c " to " c " or " c " . You end up with a support nightmare , database migration complications , more difficulty fighting injection , and other headaches . You end up with AIM style solutions where you can have spaces in your name , but they ca n't be meaningful . Also , keep in mind HTML does n't display multiple spaces in a row , so you 'd end up needing post retrieval re - parsing functions to make sure two names that differed only by number of consecutive spaces displayed without looking * exactly * the same .

question: what is actually happening when you get a " knot " in your muscle ? Edit : additional question ... is massage the only solution ? Or are there other ways to help them go back to normal ? Explain like I'm five.
responses: Muscle is striated , that means it looks sort of like hamburger in a package at the grocery store ( like long strands , all going the same way , stacked atop one another . ) Muscles are wrapped in stuff that 's like cellophane ( Saran Wrap or cling film , if you will ) . That stuff is called fascia . When you move , each little muscle strand moves and works together , it causes the fascia ( cellophane ) to rub . That friction causes the fascia to get stuck to itself and the surrounding fascia . If you get enough friction , the fascia causes the muscle to not move properly . This may cause discomfort or pain . Massage can sometimes break up these areas of knottiness . You can have someone massage the area or you can use tools like foam rollers to help . If you start with soft , light pressure , you may be able to get the muscle to relax and then through patience , get the fascia to not cling and relieve the problem . If you are too aggressive with the pressure to the area , you may cause the muscles to contract and not want to let go . Your body is smart and senses an area already under strain and to protect the damaged area , it will tense up and spasm more . That 's like taking a freshly chewed piece of gum and throwing it in the middle of the bunched up cellophane layers .

question: How can someone have both near - sightedness and far - sightedness ? Wo n’t the two effects cancel each other out ? Explain like I'm five.
responses: That is kind of like saying if it has n't rained for weeks , you are safe from a flood , because they should cancel out . Your eye focuses by using tiny muscles to make the lens flatter or rounder . When it is flattened , you can focus on distant object , when it is round , near things . The issues that prevent the lens from flattening well are completely different from those that make it harder to round . Myopia ( near - sightedness ) is usually the result of some minor congenital defect , most people retain good distant sight most of their lives . Presbyopia ( far - sightedness ) is a normal result of the focusing muscles becoming less elastic , and virtually everyone will start experiencing it in their 40s . Having one does not preclude having the other , there is no canceling .

question: How is the process of radioactive decay completely random ? I was talking with one of my professors the other day and he mentioned how you can not accurately predict the exact time an element will decay into another . So , why ? Explain like I'm five.
responses: Radioactive decay relies on probability . There is no definite amount of time that one element will take to decay into another the same way that there is no definite amount of coin tosses it would take to land a heads . Hypothetically , you could toss a coin indefinitely and never land a heads . However , when you have an incredibly large amount of atoms together , the probability of decay can essentially be thought of as the " average " time of decay . The larger the sample size , the better the approximation . If you were to take the decay time of every individual atom of a sample and plotted it , it would essentially give a bell curve , with the half - life of that element being derived from the peak . Since there is an incredibly large number of atoms in a given sample , this approximation is very good .

question: Why do bruises hurt when pressed ? I found explanations for what bruises are and why they have different colours but no information on what exactly causes the pain . Thank you Explain like I'm five.
responses: It ’s not the bruise itself- it ’s what the bruise almost always signifies , which is damaged tissue . You can get bruises that do n’t indicate damaged tissue , such as when you ’re on blood thinners or have a bleeding disorder . Then pressing a bruise wo n’t cause pain . When you get a bruise the “ old fashioned way ” , by trauma , your body gets damaged in that area . Cells become ruptured , breaking open and spilling their contents into the surrounding tissue . Some of those contents act as neurotransmitters , telling the brain to interpret that area as damaged ( pain ) , and causing us to avoid further damage . This is why pressing on a bruise hurts- our body is trying to convince us to leave it alone so it can fix the damage .

question: Why do burns blister and why do burn wounds remain warm long after the injury occurred ? Edit : Thanks , this is the first time I ever got more than 100 upvotes on anything . Ever . Explain like I'm five.
responses: I recently completed a first aid course and it was emphasized to us to cool down a burn for * 20 minutes * . This is much longer than anyone typically cools down a burn for , because in the case of minor burns you 'll start feeling relief much before then . The instructor assured us that the heat under the skin will continue to do damage in that 20 minutes if we were n't continually cooling the burn . And it kind of clicked for me when I equated it to , of all things , baking . I enjoy baking and there are some confections ( like chocolate chip cookies ) which I make sure to remove from the oven just /before/ they 're done . The logic is they will continue to retain heat , and finish baking outside the oven . So if you were to take them out when they 're " done " , by the time they have cooled they might be dry or crispy or generally overdone . A similar thing is happening with a burn . Your skin is continuing to " cook " until all the heat has dissipated . Please remember to run minor burns under lukewarm water for a full 20 minutes .

question: Why do different engines require different viscosity lubricating oils ? Why do some engines use 5w-20 as opposed to 10w-20 or 20w-50 ? Explain like I'm five.
responses: Engines are configured in different ways . Old flathead engines had all their moving parts near the oil pan . Oil did n't need to be pumped too far to get it where it needed to be . Also , clearances were looser in those engines , so a thicker ( more viscous ) oil was needed to keep the parts from wearing out prematurely . New engines have oiled parts ( e.g. camshafts ) farther away from the oil pan so the oil has to be easier to pump there . Thinner , less viscous oils work better here . Generally , you 'll find newer engines use 5W-30 or 5W-20 ( some even use 0W-20 ) oil where just a decade ago , 10W-30 was commonly used . Advances in engine design and oil formulations have allowed the use of these lighter ( runnier ) oils . If you tried to run 5W-20 in a 1965 454 , it would probably be knocking within a week .

question: What are Lagrange points and how do they work ? Wikipedia has failed me in making the concept understandable . Explain like I'm five.
responses: So first of all , all objects have a gravitational pull . This just means that all objects are constantly pulling on everything around them . The larger the objects , the stronger the pull . Using the Earth and the Sun for an example , both the earth and the sun are pulling on each other at all times . They 're actually pulling on each other with the same amount of strength , but the sun is much more massive , so it does n't really move that much . The earth on the other hand moves a lot , so the earth looks like it 's orbiting the sun But now that we 've established that everything can pull on each other , let 's imagine that there 's a tiny satellite next to the earth . It 's small enough that it does n't really have any pull on the earth or the sun , but it is influenced by both the earth and the sun . The lagrange point is the location where , if a satellite were placed , the pull of gravity from the earth and the pull of gravity from the sun as the earth orbits the sun would keep that satellite in the same place relative to the earth . So it would orbit with the same period around the sun as the earth does . Let 's draw a circle , with the sun at the very center and the earth on the edge somewhere . Now draw a line from the earth to the sun , and draw a point somewhere on that line closer to the earth than the sun . As the earth moves around the circle , so does the line . That point on the line is one of the lagrange points , and it will always be on that line between the earth and the sun . There are a total of 5 lagrange points , in different spots around the circle , which always orbit at the same rate as the larger objects

question: How do instant hand warmers work ? Not the ones with the fluid but the little pack where you just shake and it warms up Explain like I'm five.
responses: I 'm not a chemist myself , but remember researching this topic when my aunt gave me a rechargeable one for christmas years ago Rechargeable hand warmers usually work with crystallization enthalpy . They contain some fluid material that would crystallize and become solid at room temperature but can not form the first crystal which acts as the starting point for the whole process When you bend the little metal plate inside you create a little wave that starts it anyway There is an " energy gap " between the fluid and the crystallized form that gets released in form of heat in the process When heating them up to recharge them you provide enough energy to bridge this " gap " and the chemical inside gets back into its fluid state until it can crystallize again
